title: 107_s2710
content: The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage varying based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. The applicable percentage for the small business employee health insurance credit varies based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. For employers with not more than 10 qualified employees, the percentage ranges from 50 percent to a calculation involving 1.667. For qualified employees with average annual wages exceeding $10,000, the excess amount is subject to a calculation involving 50 percent and 1.667. The average annual rate of wages exceeding $10,000 for qualified employees is subject to a calculation involving 50 percent and 1.25. The excess of wages for qualified employees in a taxable year is calculated based on a percentage formula involving 50 percent and 1.25 for employers with different numbers of employees. The excess of wages for qualified employees in a taxable year is determined by a percentage formula based on the number of employees exceeding 10 and the average annual rate of wages exceeding $10,000. The formula calculates the applicable percentage for an employer based on the number of qualified employees and the average annual rate of wages exceeding $10,000. The applicable percentage is zero if determined under paragraph (2) or (3). The applicable percentage for an employer is calculated based on the average annual rate of wages exceeding $10,000. If the employer has not more than 50 qualified employees with an average annual rate of wages not exceeding $30,000, the applicable percentage shall not be less than the percentage determined under this subsection. The amount of qualified employee health insurance expenses for any taxable year shall not exceed $2,000 for self-only coverage. The limitation on qualified employee health insurance expenses is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage per employee per year. The limitation on qualified employee health insurance expenses is $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage per employee per year. Special rules and definitions apply for determining employment status. The limitation on qualified employee health insurance expenses is determined based on the portion of the entire taxable year. An employer is considered as described in subsection (b) if they employed an average number of employees on business days in the preceding calendar years. Employers must have employed an average number of employees on business days in the preceding calendar years to be considered as described in subsection (b). If the employer was not in existence throughout the 1st preceding calendar year, the determination is based on the average number of employees. Employers not in existence in the preceding year must determine the average number of employees based on the expected number for the current year. Qualified employee health insurance expenses refer to amounts paid for employee health insurance. The term 'qualified employee health insurance expenses' refers to amounts paid by an employer for health insurance coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term 'health insurance expenses' refers to employer payments for coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts from salary reduction arrangements. The term 'health insurance expenses' excludes payments from salary reduction arrangements. A 'qualified employee' is defined as someone who works more than 30 hours. The term 'qualified employee' means any employee who normally works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for subsidized health plans. A qualified employee is someone who is eligible for subsidized health plans, entitled to benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, a participant in the program under title XIX or XXI of the Act, or eligible for benefits provided to the employee. A qualified employee is eligible for benefits under title XVIII of the Social Security Act, a participant in the program under title XIX or XXI of the Act, or eligible for benefits provided under specific chapters of the United States Code. The term 'employee' does not include certain employees under specific chapters of the United States Code or any medical care program under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The term 'employee' excludes certain employees under specific chapters of the United States Code and includes leased employees. Wages are defined as per section 3121(a) without any dollar limitation. The term 'wages' is defined as per section 3121(a) without any dollar limitation. Rules similar to section 52 apply for this section, and no double benefit is allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. For purposes of this section, rules similar to section 52 apply. No double benefit is allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses under any other provision of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit for these expenses is part of the general business credit. The employee health insurance expenses credit is added to the general business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. There is no carryback of the section 45G credit before it becomes effective. The employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. The employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. A clerical amendment was made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by section 45G apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, for coverage established post-enactment of the Act.
